Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:36:22

@Steven asked > There any main tradeoffs between tessellation and mesh shading for vertex creation?

Bryon N (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:37:43

*Thread Reply:* Mesh Shading has a more flexible workflow and allows for dynamic scaling of your workload through the object shader stage. In terms of performance, Mesh Shading allows a more pipelined flow directly from the Mesh Shader stage to the rasterizer, so you have full mesh visibility during vertex creation. On the other hand - I would suggest using tessellation if you are doing actual tessellation of an existing geometry pipeline.

üëç Eric
üëæ Eric
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:38:51

*Thread Reply:* For users who are doing procedural work that doesn't directly map to tessellation per-se, I would definitely suggest Mesh Shaders.

üëÄ Bruno, Joseph
Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:41:14

*Thread Reply:* The new sample code we published shows how mesh shaders work and you can get an idea of the difference.

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:42:28

*Thread Reply:* The sample code generates Bezier patches and uses mesh shaders to control the level of detail. While the patches are generated on the CPU, you will see that it would not be a huge leap to do that in the object stage or mesh stage.

@Raul asked > Since the shaders are compiled at project build time and compilation speed is no longer as critical, is that extra headroom used to allow the compiler to try to optimize the shaders further? Or is does it produce identical machine code as when building it at runtime?

Chris N (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:10:38

*Thread Reply:* Independent from offline compilation, we did introduce a new optimization level -Os (size) as an option, but there is not additional optimization that occurs during runtime. The produced code will be identical.

@Vladislav asked > Can you explain how to use triple buffering for complicated scene with 2d (overlay/ui) and 3d? What kind of data I should store in buffers? In Vulkan examples they use framebuffer, but metal dont have any similar entity.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:18:31

*Thread Reply:* Could you give a bit more context? In general all interfacing with the compositing is done through the Drawable. (usually through a MTKView in an app). Are you referring to manually triple-buffering GPU resources for CPU synchronization?

Vladislav
2022-06-07 19:38:16

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, indeed. I wanna fill some data on CPU side while frame rendering (inflight frames) and pass filled buffer to command queue. In apple examples I see how to use inflight frames to fill camera data to buffers, but camera data isn't complicated.

Im newbie in Metal and trying to create my own render engine.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:47:08

*Thread Reply:* One way to do this is to have a set of data for each frame in flight. You can then use a mutex (or other thread-safe structure) to keep track of what sets are in flight by: ‚Ä¢ marking them when you use them in a command bufferand ‚Ä¢ unmarking them in the completion handler of the command buffer. If you run out of free sets, you can simply wait on the mutex and halt rendering on CPU until GPU has caught up.

Vladislav
2022-06-07 19:49:55

*Thread Reply:* Ok, I will try it! Thanks a lot.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:51:51

*Thread Reply:* check synchronize link and the various ways of signalling and reading data between buffers on GPU and CPU link

üëÄ Vladislav
Rohan S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:53:23

*Thread Reply:* Also, if you wanted a example of this pattern check out the game template in XCode by creating a new project in Xcode, selecting the Game template and picking Game Technology: Metal . In that template check how _inFlightSemaphore is used to multi buffer the uniforms buffer.

üòÆ Vladislav
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:54:43

*Thread Reply:* From the Dynamic Terrain Sample code: ``` // We allow up to three command buffers to be in flight on GPU before we wait static const NSUInteger kMaxBuffersInFlight = 3;

_device             = device;
_commandQueue       = [_device newCommandQueue];
_startTime          = [NSDate date];
_inFlightSemaphore  = dispatch_semaphore_create (kMaxBuffersInFlight);
_frameAllocator     = new AAPLAllocator (device, 1024 ** 1024 ** 16, kMaxBuffersInFlight);
_uniforms_gpu       = _frameAllocator-&gt;allocBuffer &lt;AAPLUniforms&gt; (1);```
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:55:15

*Thread Reply:* You can see we explicitly limit our in-flight sets to 3 in this example. (link to sample code )

Chris N (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:03:03

*Thread Reply:* The main idea is that you shouldn‚Äôt modify data with the CPU if the GPU might be reading it, so using that semaphore with a completion handler (per the examples above) allows you to know when at least one of your 3 copies of any data are able to be modified.

If you are not using the CPU to modify textures/buffers on the fly then there isn‚Äôt a need for this semaphore. -[CAMetalLayer nextDrawable] will automatically provide up to 3 drawables and will limit an app from getting too far ahead (if you render faster than the screen refresh).

üòÆ Vladislav

Vladislav
2022-06-07 20:04:53

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! I will watch linked examples asap.

We‚Äôre getting some questions about adopting the new game controllers supported by the Game Controller framework this year! Do developers have to make any code changes to take advantage of the newly supported game controllers?

üôå Sinduja S (Apple)
Justin M (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:39:33

*Thread Reply:* Nope! The newly supported game controllers will be reported to your app as GCControllerobjects, just like MFi, Xbox, and PlayStation controllers. Some new game controllers may not have all of the buttons, thumbsticks, and dpads that are available on MFi, Xbox, and PlayStation controllers. Make sure you are following the best practices outlined in the Advancements in Game Controllers talk from WWDC20 to make your game compatible with the greatest number of game controllers.

Hi everybody! Welcome to the Metal Q&A session ‚ò∫Ô∏è. We are very excited to have you all with us today. I‚Äôm Jaap, a Metal engineer at Apple. One of the big announcements this year was Metal 3, with a set of great new features and enhancements such as Fast Resource Loading, MetalFX, Ray Tracing and Mesh Shaders ü§Ø. We have already shown off a bit of these new features in our Metal session! Feel free to ask about new features, rendering, ray tracing, performance tips or maybe how to get started in this crazy world of GPU programming ü§ì.

Select the ‚ûï icon from the lower left, and find the ‚ÄúAsk A Question‚Äù workflow ‚ö°Ô∏è. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the Metal team. 2022-06-08 18:05:47

@Dan asked > Could mesh shaders be used for procedural terrain generation with continuous LOD? Currently I use a tessellation compute shader (which also does some basic culling) followed by a vertex/fragment shader.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:06:20

*Thread Reply:* You can definitely use Mesh Shaders to do this! - The great thing about Mesh Shaders is that you are not limited to the fixed tessellation layout; you can kick off an Object Shader to calculate what tiles to populate (and which ones to leave out for custom tiles), and then dynamically schedule Mesh Shader grids to create the individual tile geometry. :)

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:07:32

*Thread Reply:* This way, you could effectively generate and cull your entire terrain on the GPU

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:10:09

*Thread Reply:* Is there any specific issues you are worried/thinking about?

Dan
2022-06-08 18:11:01

*Thread Reply:* Fantastic! Are there any more details/docs on mesh shaders? I‚Äôm having trouble finding much about it.

Dan
2022-06-08 18:17:03

*Thread Reply:* One of the problems I have at the moment is culling. I pass in some quads to the tessellator, then do frustum transforms to try to figure out whether the quad would be onscreen or not (using -1 for the tessellation factor if I want to cull it). Then my vertex shader displaces vertices with the procedural function and does the transforms again, and it all feels a bit clunky.

Dan
2022-06-08 18:18:24

*Thread Reply:* I know there‚Äôs a session tomorrow on mesh shaders, but I‚Äôm having trouble understanding the basic behavior of them atm.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:19:45

*Thread Reply:* There will be a full session on Mesh Shaders tomorrow! And you can always drop back into the next Q&A on friday if you have any follow-up.

My suggestion for doing these kinds of things, is to assume each "tile" has a AABB of the min/max displacement within the segment (pre-calc if needed), then use the Object Shader (which is a full featured compute shader) to generate work items for tiles of various sizes etc. Then run a Mesh Shader Grid with a TG per tile to generate. You can simply cull your AABB in the OS and you should never have any overhead aside from the AABB check üôÇ

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:21:08

*Thread Reply:* You can effectively have the OS TG fill the payload buffer with an array of TileDesc structs (or something like that), then have each MS TG pick up a TileDesc to expand into a mesh and send it straight to the rasterizer

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:23:36

*Thread Reply:* Tomorrow's Mesh Shader session will be here: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10162/ Documentation will be updated in the near future, and I believe a sample project will be available along with the session.

2022-06-08 18:45:09

*Thread Reply:* I think the main issue with the classic tessellation scheme is that it tends to generate noisy silhouettes when tessellation smoothly increases. (you get this wave-effect as the vertices move across the displacement samples). There should be a way to integrate an external "classic tessellation function" into the MS kernel to generate a list of 2D triples for a given tessellation. I wouldn't be surprised if there are examples of this online.

@Oleksii asked > What is the best way to denoise the Ray traced frame in metal? Is MPSSVGFDenoiser recommended for this purpose?

Rich F (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:25:06

*Thread Reply:* MPSSVGFDenoiser will work for denoising the full application frame. Typically you want a denoiser targeted at each ray traced effect, focusing on the visibility signal for shadows and ambient occlusion, and a separate denoiser for reflections aware of how to reproject reflected content.

üëç Oleksii
Oleksii
2022-06-08 18:26:45

*Thread Reply:* thanks for the response

Rich F (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:28:54

*Thread Reply:* üëç Denoising is a rapidly moving field and there's several open source options that you could look at adding to your application!

üëç Josiah
Oleksii
2022-06-08 18:49:20

*Thread Reply:* Those are new topics for me, so sorry if it is a silly question, but what is the latest best way to organize global illumination passes with metal ray tracing then? In my inexperienced understanding it was like: accumulate the light from ~3 bounces and apply denoising to the whole result

Rich F (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:17:19

*Thread Reply:* Not a silly question at all! Accumulating light from multiple bounces will result in an approximation to global illumination and will likely be noisy depending on how you define the rays for each bounce. Typically for later bounces you could accept something more diffuse for your global illumination representation - there's more diffuse representations such as Dynamic Diffuse Global Illumination

2022-06-08 18:55:48

Dan
2022-06-08 18:58:02

*Thread Reply:* I think it‚Äôs not a CAMetalLayer, which is the problem. I think it‚Äôs using CAShapeLayer, CATextLayer, etc. (which are much simpler than implementing text rendering for instance). Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:58:22

*Thread Reply:* Most generally, the only way to capture the composited appearance of a layer is via CARenderer. You will have difficulty syncing the framerate of this renderer with the display.

Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:58:42

*Thread Reply:* CARenderer is available on iOS, can you elaborate on your difficulty with it?

Dan
2022-06-08 19:03:15

*Thread Reply:* Hmm.. I could have sworn that CARenderer::rendererWithMTLTexture was not available on iOS.. but the docs says it has been there since iOS 11.

Dan
2022-06-08 19:03:33

*Thread Reply:* Well, I think that‚Äôs the way to do it, right?

Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:04:21

*Thread Reply:* One difference I can think of between macOS and iOS is that iOS makes much heavier use of implicit CATransactions. If you try to render the layer tree while the main queue‚Äôs implicit transaction is still open, you might not capture the latest drawing.

On iOS, to guarantee correct drawing, use UIGraphicsImageRenderer in conjunction with -[UIView drawViewHierarchyInRect:afterScreenUpdates:YES]. You can then use the resulting UIImage to populate an MTLTexture. This will not be as fast as using CARenderer directly but it is more likely to be resilient to the complexities of how iOS apps use Core Animation.

Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:04:37

*Thread Reply:* But do try CARenderer first. üôÇ

Dan
2022-06-08 19:09:26

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I‚Äôll take another look!

Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:10:18

*Thread Reply:* Good luck! If neither approach works for you, please file Feedback so the teams involved can understand more about your use case.

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:48:51

*Thread Reply:* Devices with an XDR display currently support EDR as long as the device brightness isn't set too high (among other factors) which would clamp those EDR values. Please see https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/hdr_content/determining_support_for_edr_values?language=objc for more details. On macOS, you can read the maximumPotentialExtendedDynamicRangeColorComponentValue property on an NSScreen object for that display. And on iOS, you can use UIScreen.potentialEDRHeadroom.

Tijmen
2022-06-08 18:50:45

*Thread Reply:* Is the iPhone 13 Pro included in this?

Pierre M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:01:00

*Thread Reply:* I haven't tested it, but I think you should get a large EDR headroom on iPhone 13 pro.

üëç Chris N (Apple), Tijmen
Alexey V (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:20:41

*Thread Reply:* We also recommend to poll the value of UIScreen.currentEDRHeadroom (for iOS) or NSScreen.maximumExtendedDynamicRangeColorComponentValue (for macOS) to accommodate for possible display brightness changes that might affect available headroom. Those can be caused for ex. by the user interaction - changing the screen brightness or by the system if auto-brightness setting is enabled or as a result of thermal event when device has to throttle.

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:55:04

@Maxwell asked > More out of curiosity, what are the potential use cases of quadgroup functions? I've only seen one video mentioning them ("Discovering advances in Metal for A15 Bionic") where they're used to reduce the number of texture reads per thread. Are there any other use "common" use cases?

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:55:19

*Thread Reply:* It can be used for any workload where you want to spread orthogonal work across a group; for instance, you can have each thread in a quad cull a part of a light list, then use quadgroup functions to peek at each others' lists and sum lights.

Kelvin C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:56:01

*Thread Reply:* The gist of quadgroup and simdgroup functions are to perform data exchange in a more efficient manner. Traditionally, threadgroup barrier and threadgroup memory is required to perform data exchanges, but its a lot more heavier than finer granularity exchanges like quadgroup or simdgroup functions.

Maxwell
2022-06-08 18:56:50

*Thread Reply:* When would you decide to use a quadgroup over a simdgroup function?

Kelvin C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:57:35

*Thread Reply:* When all you need is to exchange among 4 threads in a row.

üëç Maxwell
Kelvin C (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:59:36

*Thread Reply:* The finer granularity you use, the more efficient it is.

Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:00:36

*Thread Reply:* If you are in compute, I would probably always use simdgroup, just to get the best bang for your buck. I believe quadgroups are interesting for fragment workloads; I'm not sure what the availability and details are by heart. (rasterization, helper threads etc)

üëç Maxwell

üëÄ Djavan
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:57:20

*Thread Reply:* Are you using individual nodes for each letter/glyph? If so, I would recommend "baking" the glyphs into a vertex/index buffer at run-time and then inserting the entire mesh as a single node.

‚ù§Ô∏è Ivan
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:00:24

*Thread Reply:* So for instance, you would read in the text, then generate the mesh for a single page, and add that page to your scene as a single mesh (that you can then modify as if it is a static mesh).

Alternatively, you can simply generate a large image with all the text on it using our Text APIs and simply apply it as a texture/Image.

üíØ Ivan
Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:00:51

*Thread Reply:* But the latter would take up more memory as you are effectively creating a full-sized texture each time.

Ivan
2022-06-08 20:36:07

*Thread Reply:* Jaap, thanks for your time! That‚Äôs exactly the case - at the moment, I render each glyph as a node, and then flatten() them into a single geometry.

2022-06-08 20:43:45

*Thread Reply:* I have a large texture method too, and it does work, but indeed has the memory issue you‚Äôre mentioning.

If I were to generate the mesh, is there something that I could use as a sample to convert a node‚Äôs general presentation / backing geometry to a mesh? I apologize if that‚Äôs a vague question. Jaap van M (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:50:36

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Ivan, sorry for the late reply, as we closed down the Q&A, but if you want to discuss this more, please drop by the Q&A on Friday, or sign up for a Developer Lab, which is a 1:1 in-depth chat with one of our developers!

Just to quickly reply to your question, I do agree that you probably want to do this manually to remove a lot of the overhead. I'm not sure how familiar you are with mesh representations, but you should probably be able to do this by effectively writing your own "flatten" function. Without knowing where most of the performance is lost, I would suggest reading the nodes data manually and then composing the vertices for the mesh yourself. This would require you to manually create vertex and index data for your mesh and then upload and bind these to your Mesh.

I would suggest putting your question up in the Labs and indicate this is a SceneKit question - I think those folks will be better equipped to point out the best path :)

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

@Josiah asked > With MetalFX are there any concerns or issues when dealing with transparency/volumetrics when doing temporal upscaling? Would it sometimes be better to use Spatial upscaling and MSAA in some cases with a lot of transparency?

Yaroslav B (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:05:22

*Thread Reply:* Temporal AA requires full motion and depth information to produce the best result. Transparent objects usually do not provide that, so TAA will have insufficient input data to process everything correctly. Similar logic applies to reflections.

Yaroslav B (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:08:43

*Thread Reply:* The choice will depend on your particular setup of the rendering pipeline. You could apply temporal upscaling to lower resolution color buffer with opaque objects only and then render transparent objects and volumetrics on top (in output resolution).

Josiah
2022-06-08 20:10:44

*Thread Reply:* That makes sense, thanks. Would the upscalers also work for targets other than the final tone mapped image, ie an AO pass?

Yaroslav B (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:20:15

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you can do that. Just allocate separate scaling effect instances for those.

2022-06-08 20:31:05

*Thread Reply:* Hi Michael! Yes, system level permission (one time) is required for the initial time any applications wants to use ScreenCaptureKit. Even if the application is capturing itself, it'll need to get the SCShareableContent list in order to create a filter, which requires system level permission on the initial use.

@Jeffrey asked > Our video conferencing app offers screen sharing functionality, but we want the screen share video to exclude certain windows (e.g., A/V controls and floating participant videos). This is easily solvable with content filtering in ScreenCaptureKit, but what is the recommended way to get this behavior with older versions of macOS that do not support ScreenCaptureKit?

Drew M (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:30:02

*Thread Reply:* You can use the screen capture portion of ScreenCaptureKit as of 12.3, and send it to other users using earlier versions of macOS. In order to get the maximum screen capture performance with ScreenCaptureKit, you'll need 12.3 or later. To achieve similar behavior in previous versions of macOS, you can use the CGWindow API to capture video, but not audio.

Mark
2022-06-08 21:01:59

*Thread Reply:* Specifically, CGWindowListCreate() and CGWindowListCreateImage(). They‚Äôre much slower than the other APIs, but available back to earlier MacOS versions.

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:36:17

@Joseph asked > If you want to display the interactions with menu at the top of macOS, does that constrain you to just capturing a display (vs. application or window) in order to show that?

Drew M (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:36:40

*Thread Reply:* You can use init(display:including:exceptingWindows:), but this will capture the surface the size of the desktop. The app will be positioned as it is in the desktop, and the menu bar will be at the top of the capture.

@Sotiris asked > Why use a constant jitter offset for a set of pixels instead of a random one that would probably make the result more smoother?

Alex K (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:52:04

*Thread Reply:* Using a fixed set of low-discrepancy jitter offsets ensures that the space of potential jitters is covered relatively evenly for any given window in time.

2022-06-08 23:11:10

@Sotiris asked > Wonderful presentation @Kevin! Thank you very much! The technology works beautifully with slow moving scenes. Kelvin C (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:53:13

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. If the scene is truly moving super quick, where there's very little temporal information that can be reused, the result will simply not be as high resolution and anti-aliased. Seth L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:09:59

*Thread Reply:* To offscreen render a scene and save it as a PNG file, you may first render the scene into a MTLTexture with the desired resolution. The texture will need to be a <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtltextureusage/1515701-rendertarget |render target>.

Then there are a few different ways to get a CGImage from the MTLTexture: A quick way will be to <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coreimage/ciimage/1437890-init |initialize a CIImage> with the MTLTexture and then <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coreimage/cicontext/1437784-createcgimage |use a CIContext to create the CGImage>, which you can use to write to disk.

Alexey
2022-06-08 23:10:57

*Thread Reply:* Oh, thank you so much for the answer!!!

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:13:29

@Andrew asked > what is the fastest way to get something on screen with Metal? is there way to draw directly to screen instead of metal layer contents and then wait for frame composing?

Kyle S (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:13:42

*Thread Reply:* The fastest way to get your drawing on-screen is to create a full-screen CAMetalLayer. You can also optionally set displaySyncEnabled to false on your layer to render faster than the display‚Äôs refresh rate at the cost of potential artifacts.

Chris N (Apple)
2022-06-10 18:10:12

*Thread Reply:* Be sure to take advantage of a ProMotion display if the user has it, too! You can set a minimum and maximum CADisplayLink callback rate using a CAFrameRateRange, for instance.

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:32:53

@Karl asked > Might anyone be able to speak to whether it makes sense to combine indirect command buffers (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/indirectcommandencoding/encodingindirectcommandbuffersonthegpu?language=objc ) with bindless rendering and dynamic data? Specifically, I am trying to avoid a lot of draw calls. With the SOC architecture, it seems passing data is not really expensive, so I figure per-frame I could just specify some parameters and generate draw calls on the GPU, as in the example. > > -broad question, I realize, but I'd appreciate some thoughts on how to reduce draw calls for rapidly-updated and/or deleted vertex data. > > I also checked mesh shaders, but I think those are overkill for my use case.

Al√® S (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:34:01

*Thread Reply:* Hi Karl! Metal 3 adds support for starting raytracing work from ICBs. ICBs give you more flexibility at rendering time, but this flexibility does come with a cost that will vary according to your specific use case. For example ICBs will give you the edge when you are CPU-bound. As with all things related to performance, we recommend you profile your game (or app) üôÇ

Karl
2022-06-09 22:32:50

Jared M (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:15:59

*Thread Reply:* Ok, interesting. Well, as I'm sure you've seen there's a ton of resource for learning C++. If you're used to Obj-C, I think you'll understand the basic concepts pretty quickly.

The reason I ask is because Metal is natively implemented as an Objective-C API. What's nice about Objective-C++ is that inter-op with C++ is super easy. Basically, you just rename your .m files to .mm files and you're using Objective-C++. You can now include C++ headers and start playing immediately.

Now, if you really want to use Metal-cpp I don't want to discourage you at all. It's great to see developers interested. I think it's worth noting, though, that if you want to go the 'pure' C++ route, you'll likely need to end up wrapping some of our other platform libraries which are exposed as Obj-C or Swift.

üëç Josiah

@Peter asked > Is there any documentation for the new Metal Pipeline Script JSON format? > > Mentioned in the "Target and optimize GPU binaries with Metal 3" session.

:the_horns: Karan V (Apple)
Chris N (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:34:47

*Thread Reply:* Official documentation is coming soon! In the meantime here is a quick overview of creating a pre-compiled MTLBinaryArchive:

First create a MTLBinaryArchive using the existing API. After that is done you can extract the Metal Pipeline JSON with: $ metal-source -flatbuffers=json theBinaryArchive.metallib -o /tmp/descriptors.mtlp-json

Then you can use the mtlp-json file with metal to generate a MTLBinaryArchive offline that will work with all GPUs: $ metal shaders.metal -N descriptors.mtlp-json -o archive.metallib

Chris N (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:36:20

*Thread Reply:* Here is a link to the talk for others who may be interested in more: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10102/

Apple Developer
Target and optimize GPU binaries with Metal 3 - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover how you can reduce in-app stutters, first launch times, and new level load times when you generate your GPU binaries entirely at...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10102/

*Thread Reply:* I harvested the archive using (swift)... ```let lib = device.makeDefaultLibrary()! let desc = MTLRenderPipelineDescriptor() desc.vertexFunction = lib.makeFunction(name: "vertmain") desc.fragmentFunction = lib.makeFunction(name: "fragmain") desc.colorAttachments[0]?.pixelFormat = .bgra8Unorm

let archdesc = MTLBinaryArchiveDescriptor()

let archive = try device.makeBinaryArchive(descriptor: archdesc) try archive.addRenderPipelineFunctions(descriptor: desc) try archive.serialize(to: NSURL.fileURL(withPath: "/Users/pwong/Downloads/x-game.metallib"))```

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:00:15

*Thread Reply:* Hi, thanks for your question. Since Metal doesn't support the double data type, you would have to use (or make) an arbitrary precision floating point library. Another option is to use 64-bit integers using fixed-point approaches. We would also encourage you to send a report with your use case using Feedback Assistant so the team can consider it as a future enhancement.

Jonathan M (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* Also, I want to add to my answer that you could also experiment with the "fast-math" option that is normally turned on by default. If you disable it, you may get a little better precision in your results when calling sin, cos, sqrt, etc. It's not the same thing as a 64-bit floating point type of course, but handy if you're debugging a precision issue.

Graphics and Games - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 20:05:49

@Jack asked > Is there a way to reference templated compute functions from a compute pipeline descriptor such that the templated type inherits the bound texture's pixel format?

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:09:37

*Thread Reply:* Hi, this sounds like an interesting question. For example sake (using non-real code), I think you are trying to ask if you can do something like template &lt;typename T&gt; void computeShader(...) { ... } in your shader code and then reference this function using something like id &lt;MTLFunction&gt; function = [defaultLibrary newFunctionWithName:@"computeShader&lt;MyType&gt;"]; Is that what you are asking?

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:16:49

*Thread Reply:* You can use the host_name attribute and then define your template specializations. In the Metal Shading Language Specification, section 5.1.10 and 5.1.11 show how you can change the name that Metal will use to reference the function name.

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:32:21

*Thread Reply: For example, you could try something like: ```template <typename MyType> kernel void computeShader(device MyType* output, constant MyType &argument) { **output = argument; }

template [[hostname("computeShaderint")]] kernel void computeShader<int>(device int** output, constant int &argument);

template [[hostname("computeShaderfloat")]] kernel void computeShader<float>(device float** output, constant float &argument); And then reference the functions in your app with: id <MTLFunction> function1 = [defaultLibrary newFunctionWithName:@"computeShaderint"]; id <MTLFunction> function2 = [defaultLibrary newFunctionWithName:@"computeShaderfloat"];```

Jack
2022-06-10 20:53:16

*Thread Reply:* @Jonathan M (Apple) Yes, your example illustrates what I was looking for. So sounds like I'd still need to create a compute pipeline state per pixel format?

Jack
2022-06-10 20:54:39

*Thread Reply:* For context, I was hoping to build my compute pipeline state once up front and allow a consumer of an MPS-like framework provide textures with various pixel formats.

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:57:03

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you would need to create a pipeline state for each one.

üëç Jack
Jack
2022-06-10 20:57:04

*Thread Reply:* Something like: template &lt;typename T&gt; void computeShader(texture2d&lt;T&gt; myTexture [[texture(0)]]) { ... } where T is inferred from texture(0)

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 20:58:35

*Thread Reply:* And the reason for that is so the compiler can create an optimized version for each permutation you have.

Jack
2022-06-10 21:00:02

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, makes sense. Would be cool if a compute pipeline state could be build with a set of template parameter permutations and then it selects the correct one based on bindings

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 21:00:08

*Thread Reply:* In fact, the term "shader permutations" refers to this specialization whether you're using templates, or function constants.

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 21:02:26

*Thread Reply:* If the pipeline is built too late though, it could trigger the compiler and that can result in performance problems. So, if you had a choice to compile your shaders before your app begins, versus on-demand, it's preferable to do it before.

Jack
2022-06-10 21:04:00

*Thread Reply:* I see, so without template specialization in the shader source, the pipeline would have to compile versions for each of the permutations set on the pipeline state

Jack
2022-06-10 21:05:05

*Thread Reply:* For the use case I outlined above, would you recommend lazily constructing the necessary pipeline state objects or building all possible versions once up front?

Jonathan M (Apple)
2022-06-10 21:07:51

*Thread Reply:* If you know that you will need to use all possible ones, then you should do it once up front. Consider a real-time graphics application with many kinds of materials. If you were to compile the pipeline state objects when they were needed, then you may get stutters while you wait for them to compile.

Jack
2022-06-10 21:08:36

*Thread Reply:* Great, thanks for your responses, very informative!

üòÄ Jonathan M (Apple)
